docs.lead_paragraph: AT a boisterous prepublication open house recently, Sheryl E. Huggins, the publisher of Shade, weaved through a crowd of black artists, writers, photographers and others, music from A Tribe Called Quest booming from the stereo. There in one room at the magazine's Manhattan office, wearing everything from business suits to dreadlocks, was a microcosm of the diverse readership Ms. Huggins hopes to attract when Shade makes its debut in March -- a microcosm, too, of a black diversity that has fostered a flurry of new magazines.
